question: Question_01_(j)
statement:
Let \emph{f} and \emph{g} be functions such that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f'(x)\end{align*}

and

\begin{align*}\displaystyle g'(x)\end{align*}

are both continuous and increasing for all real numbers \emph{x}. Which
of the following is ALWAYS true?

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \emph{f} + \emph{g} is concave up everywhere
\item
  \emph{f} - \emph{g} is concave up everywhere
\item
  \emph{f} Â· \emph{g} is concave up everywhere
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  I only
\item
  II only
\item
  I and II only
\item
  I and III only
\item
  I, II, and III
\end{enumerate}
hints:
What do you know about $f''(x)$ and $g''(x)$ from the statement of the
problem?

To test (I), define a function $H = f + g$. What is the value of the
second derivative of $H$?

You can use a similar method to test II and III.
